CRFL: Certifiably Robust Federated Learning against Backdoor Attacks

Chulin Xie    Minghao Chen    Pin-Yu Chen    Bo Li
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) as a distributed learning paradigm that aggregates information from diverse clients to train a shared global model, has demonstrated great success. However, malicious clients can perform poisoning attacks and model replacement to introduce backdoors into the trained global model. Although there have been intensive studies designing robust aggregation methods and empirical robust federated training protocols against backdoors, existing approaches lack robustness certification. This paper provides the first general framework, Certifiably Robust Federated Learning (CRFL), to train certifiably robust FL models against backdoors. Our method exploits clipping and smoothing on model parameters to control the global model smoothness, which yields a sample-wise robustness certification on backdoors with limited magnitude. Our certification also specifies the relation to federated learning parameters, such as poisoning ratio on instance level, number of attackers, and training iterations. Practically, we conduct comprehensive experiments across a range of federated datasets, and provide the ﬁrst benchmark for certiﬁed robustness against backdoor attacks in federated learning. Our code is publicaly available at https://github.com/AI-secure/CRFL.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has been widely applied to different applications given its high efficiency and privacy-preserving properties (Smith et al., 2017; McMahan et al., 2017a; Zhao et al., 2018). However, recent studies show that it is easy for the local client to add adversarial perturbation such as “backdoors” during training to compromise the final aggregated model (Bhagoji et al., 2019; Bagdasaryan et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2020; Xie et al., 2019). Such attacks raise great security concerns and have become the roadblocks towards the real-world deployment of federated learning.

Although there have been intensive studies on robust FL by designing robust aggregation methods (Fung et al., 2020; Pillutla et al., 2019; Fu et al., 2019; Blanchard et al., 2017; El Mhamdi et al., 2018; Chen et al., 2017; Yin et al., 2018), developing empirically robust federated training protocols (e.g., gradient clipping (Sun et al., 2019), leveraging noisy perturbation (Sun et al., 2019) and additional evaluation during training (Andreina et al., 2020)), current defense approaches lack robustness guarantees against the backdoor attacks under certain conditions. To the best of our knowledge, certified robustness analysis and algorithms for FL against backdoor attacks remain elusive.

To bridge this gap, in this work we propose a certifiably robust federated learning (CRFL) framework as illustrated in Figure 1. In particular, during training, we allow the local agent to update their model parameters to the center server, and the server will: 1) aggregate the collected model updates, 2) clip the norm of the aggregated model parameters, 3) add a random noise to the clipped model, and finally 4) send the new model parameters back to each agent. Note that all of the operations are conducted on the server side to reduce the load for local clients and to prevent malicious clients. During testing, the server will smooth the final global model with randomized parameter smoothing and make the final prediction based on the parameter-smoothed model.

Using CRFL, we theoretically prove that the trained global model would be certifiably robust against backdoors as long as the backdoor is within our certified bound. To obtain such robustness certification, we first quantify the closeness of models aggregated in each step by viewing this process as a Markov Kernel (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020; Makur, 2019; Polyanskiy & Wu, 2015, 2017). We then leverage the model closeness together with the parameter smoothing procedure to certify the final prediction. Empirically, we conduct extensive evaluations on MNIST, EMNIST, and financial datasets to evaluate the certified robustness of CRFL and study how FL parameters affect certified robustness.

Technical Contributions. In this paper, we take the first step towards providing certified robustness for FL against backdoor attacks. We make contributions on both theoretical and empirical fronts.

  • •

    We propose the first certifiably robust federated learning (CRFL) framework against backdoor attacks.

  • •

    Theoretically, we analyze the training dynamics of the aggregated model via Markov Kernel, and propose parameter smoothing for model inference. Altogether, we prove the certified robustness of CRFL.

  • •

    We conduct extensive experiments on MNIST, EMNIST, and financial datasets to show the effect of different FL parameters (e.g. poisoning ratio, number of attackers, and training iterations) on certified robustness.

2 Related work

Backdoor Attacks on Federated Learning

The goal of backdoor attacks against federated learning is to train strong poisoned local models and submit malicious model updates to the central server, so as to mislead the global model (Bhagoji et al., 2019). (Bagdasaryan et al., 2020) studies the model replacement approach, where the attacker scales malicious model updates to replace the global model with local backdoored one. (Xie et al., 2019) exploit the decentralized nature of federated learning and propose a distributed backdoor attack.

Robust Federated Learning

In order to nullify the effects of attacks while aggregating client updates, a number of robust aggregation algorithms have been proposed for distributed learning (Fung et al., 2020; Pillutla et al., 2019; Fu et al., 2019; Blanchard et al., 2017; El Mhamdi et al., 2018; Chen et al., 2017; Yin et al., 2018). These methods either identify and down-weight the malicious updates through certain distance or similarity metrics, or estimate a true “center” of the received model updates rather than taking a weighted average. However, many of those methods assume that the data distribution is i.i.d cross distributed clients, which is not the case in FL setting. Other defenses are several robust federated protocols that mitigate poisoning attacks during training. (Andreina et al., 2020) incorporates an additional validation phase to each round of FL to detect backdoor. (Sun et al., 2019) show that clipping the norm of model updates and adding Gaussian noise can mitigate backdoor attacks that are based on the model replacement paradigm. None of these provides certified robustness guarantees.

A concurrent work (Cao et al., 2021) proposes Ensemble FL for provable secure FL against malicious clients, which requires training hundreds of FL models and focuses on client-level certification. Our work allows standard FL protocol, and our certification is applicable to feature, sample, and client levels.

So we formulate the SGD problem in FL as Periodic Averaging SGD (Wang & Joshi, 2019; Li et al., 2020). 3.2 Threat Model

The goal of backdoor is to inject a backdoor pattern during training such that any test input with such pattern will be mis-classified as the target label (Gu et al., 2019). The purpose of backdoor attacks in FL is to manipulate local models and simultaneously fit the main task and backdoor task, so that the global model would behave normally on untampered data samples while achieving high attack success rate on backdoored data samples. We consider the backdoor attack via model replacement approach (Bagdasaryan et al., 2020) where the attackers train the local models using the poisoned datasets, and scale the malicious updates before sending it to the sever. Suppose there are R𝑅R adversarial clients out of N𝑁N clients, we assume that each of them only attack once and they perform model replacement attack together at the same round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}. Such distributed yet coordinated backdoor attack is shown to be effective in (Xie et al., 2019).

For a data sample zji:={xji,yji}assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖z_{j}^{i}:=\{x_{j}^{i},y_{j}^{i}\} in Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}, we denote its backdoored version as z′ji:={xji+δix,yji+δiy}assignsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑧′𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑖subscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖subscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑦{z^{\prime}}_{j}^{i}:=\{x_{j}^{i}+{{\delta_{i}}_{x}},y_{j}^{i}+{{\delta_{i}}_{y}}\}, and the backdoor as δi:={δix,δiy}assignsubscript𝛿𝑖subscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑥subscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑦\delta_{i}:=\{{\delta_{i}}_{x},{\delta_{i}}_{y}\}. 4 Methodology

In this Section, we introduce our proposed framework CRFL, which is composed of a training-time subroutine (Algorithm 1) and a test-time subroutine (Algorithm 2) for achieving certified robustness.

4.1 CRFL Training: Clipping and Perturbing

During training, at round t=1,…,T−1𝑡1…𝑇1t=1,\ldots,T-1, local clients update their models, and the server performs aggregation. 4.2 CRFL Testing: Parameter Smoothing

Smoothed Classifiers

We study multi-class classification models and define a classifier h:(𝒲,𝒳)→𝒴:ℎ→𝒲𝒳𝒴h:\mathcal{(W,X)}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} with finite set of label 𝒴={1,…,C}𝒴1…𝐶\mathcal{Y}=\{1,\ldots,C\}, where C𝐶C denotes the number of classes. We extend the randomized smoothing method (Cohen et al., 2019) to parameter smoothing for constructing a new, “smoothed” classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} from an arbitrary base classifier hℎh. The robustness properties can be verified using the smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s}. Given the model parameter w𝑤w of hℎh, when queried at a test sample xt​e​s​tsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡x_{test}, we first take a majority vote over the predictions of the base classifier hℎh on random model parameters drawn from a probability distribution μ𝜇\mu, i.e., the smoothing measure, to obtain the “votes” Hsc​(w;xt​e​s​t)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{H_{s}^{c}}(w;x_{test}) for each class c∈𝒴𝑐𝒴c\in\mathcal{Y}. Then the label returned by the smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is the mostly probable label among all classes (the majority vote winner). Formally,

hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)=arg⁡maxc∈𝒴⁡Hsc​(w;xt​e​s​t),subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝒴superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\displaystyle{h_{s}}(w;x_{test})=\arg\max_{c\in\mathcal{Y}}{H_{s}^{c}}(w;x_{test}), (1)
where ​Hsc​(w;xt​e​s​t)=ℙW∼μ​(w)​[h​(W;xt​e​s​t)=c].where superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜇𝑤delimited-[]ℎ𝑊subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐\displaystyle\text{where }{H_{s}^{c}}(w;x_{test})=\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\mu(w)}[h(W;x_{test})=c].

To be aligned with the training time Gaussian noise (perturbing), we also adopt Gaussian smoothing measures μ​(w)=𝒩​(w,σT2​𝐈)𝜇𝑤𝒩𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑇2𝐈\mu(w)=\mathcal{N}(w,{\sigma_{T}}^{2}\bf I) during testing time. In practice, the exact value of the probability pc=ℙW∼μ​(w)​[h​(W;xt​e​s​t)=c]subscript𝑝𝑐subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜇𝑤delimited-[]ℎ𝑊subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐p_{c}=\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\mu(w)}[h(W;x_{test})=c] for label c𝑐c is difficult to obtain for neural networks, and hence we resort to Monte Carlo estimation (Cohen et al., 2019; Lecuyer et al., 2019) to get its approximation p^csubscript^𝑝𝑐\hat{p}_{c}. At round t=T𝑡𝑇t=T, given the clipped aggregated global model ClipρT​(wT)subscriptClipsubscript𝜌𝑇subscript𝑤𝑇\mathrm{Clip}_{\rho_{T}}({w_{T}}), we add Gaussian noise ϵTk∼𝒩​(0,σT2​𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇𝑘𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑇2𝐈\epsilon_{T}^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{T}^{2}\bf I) for M𝑀M times to get M𝑀M sets of noisy model parameters (M𝑀M Monte Carlo samples for estimation), such that w~Tk←ClipρT​(wT)+ϵTk,k=1,2,…,M.formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript~𝑤𝑇𝑘subscriptClipsubscript𝜌𝑇subscript𝑤𝑇superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇𝑘𝑘12…𝑀\widetilde{w}_{T}^{k}\leftarrow\mathrm{Clip}_{\rho_{T}}({w_{T}})+\epsilon_{T}^{k},\leavevmode\nobreak\ k=1,2,\ldots,M.

In Algorithm 2, The function GetCountsGetCounts\mathrm{GetCounts} runs the classifier with each set of noisy model parameters wTksuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑇𝑘w_{T}^{k} for one test sample xt​e​s​tsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡x_{test}, and returns a vector of class counts. Then we take the most probable class c^Asubscript^𝑐𝐴\hat{c}_{A} and the runner-up class c^Bsubscript^𝑐𝐵\hat{c}_{B} to calculate the corresponding p^Asubscript^𝑝𝐴\hat{p}_{A} and p^Bsubscript^𝑝𝐵\hat{p}_{B}. The function CalculateBoundCalculateBound\mathrm{CalculateBound} calibrates the empirical estimation to bound the probability α𝛼\alpha of hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} returning an incorrect label. Given the error tolerance α𝛼\alpha, we use Hoeffding’s inequality (Hoeffding, 1994) to compute a lower bound pA¯¯subscript𝑝𝐴\underline{p_{A}} on the probability HscA​(w;xt​e​s​t)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠subscript𝑐𝐴𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡H_{s}^{c_{A}}(w;x_{test}) and a upper bound pB¯¯subscript𝑝𝐵\overline{p_{B}} on the probability HscB​(w;xt​e​s​t)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠subscript𝑐𝐵𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡H_{s}^{c_{B}}(w;x_{test}) according to pA¯=p^A−log⁡(1/α)2​N¯subscript𝑝𝐴subscript^𝑝𝐴1𝛼2𝑁\underline{p_{A}}=\hat{p}_{A}-\sqrt{\frac{\log(1/\alpha)}{2N}}, pB¯=p^B+log⁡(1/α)2​N¯subscript𝑝𝐵subscript^𝑝𝐵1𝛼2𝑁\overline{p_{B}}=\hat{p}_{B}+\sqrt{\frac{\log(1/\alpha)}{2N}}. We leave the function CalculateRadiusCalculateRadius\mathrm{CalculateRadius} to be defined with our main results in later sections and we will analyze the robustness properties of the model trained and tested under our framework CRFL.

Comparison with Certifiably Robust Models in Centralized Setting

Our method is different from previous certifiably robust models in centralized learning against evasion attacks (Cohen et al., 2019) and backdoors (Weber et al., 2020). Once the M𝑀M noisy models (at round T𝑇T, with σTsubscript𝜎𝑇\sigma_{T}) are generated, they are fixed and used for every test sample during test time, just like RAB (Weber et al., 2020) in the centralized setting. However, RAB actually trains M𝑀M models using M𝑀M noise-corrupted datasets, while we just train one model through FL and finally generated M𝑀M noise-corrupted copies of it. For every test sample, randomized smoothing (Cohen et al., 2019) generates M𝑀M noisy samples. Suppose the test set size is m𝑚m. Then during testing, there are m⋅M⋅𝑚𝑀m\cdot M times noise addition on test samples for randomized smoothing, and M𝑀M times noises addition on trained model for CRFL. To our best knowledge, this is the first work to study parameter smoothing rather than input smoothing, which is an open problem motivated by the FL scenario, since the sever directly aggregates over the model parameters.

5 Certified Robustness of CRFL

5.1 Pointwise Certified Robustness

Goal of Certification

In the context of data poisoning in federated learning, the goal is to protect the global model against adversarial data modification made to the local training sets of distributed clients. Thus, the goal of certifiable robustness in federated learning is for each test point, to return a prediction as well as a certificate that the prediction would not change had some features in (part of) local training data of certain clients been modified.

Following our threat model in Section 3.2 and our training protocol in Algorithm 1, we define the trained global model ℳ​(D′):=ClipρT​(w′T).assignℳsuperscript𝐷′subscriptClipsubscript𝜌𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑇\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}):=\mathrm{Clip}_{\rho_{T}}({w^{\prime}}_{T}). For the FL training process that is exposed to model replacement attack, when the distance between D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} (backdoored dataset) and D𝐷D (clean dataset) is under certain threshold (i.e., the magnitude of {{δi}j=1qi}i=1Rsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑞𝑖𝑖1𝑅\{\{\delta_{i}\}_{j=1}^{q_{i}}\}_{i=1}^{R} is bounded), we can certify that ℳ​(D′)ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) is “close” to ℳ​(D)ℳ𝐷\mathcal{M}(D) and thus is robust to backdoors. The rationale lies in the fact that we perform clipping and noise perturbation on the model parameters to control the global model deviation during training. During testing, intuitively, under the Gaussian smoothing measures μ𝜇\mu as described in Algorithm 2, for two close distribution μ​(ℳ​(D′))𝜇ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) and μ​(ℳ​(D))𝜇ℳ𝐷\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)), we would expect that even though the probabilities for each class c𝑐c, i.e., Hsc​(ℳ​(D′);xt​e​s​t)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐ℳsuperscript𝐷′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{H_{s}^{c}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test}) and Hsc​(ℳ​(D);xt​e​s​t)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐ℳ𝐷subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{H_{s}^{c}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test}), may not be equal, the returned most likely label hs​(ℳ​(D′);xt​e​s​t)subscriptℎ𝑠ℳsuperscript𝐷′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test}) and hs​(ℳ​(D);xt​e​s​t)subscriptℎ𝑠ℳ𝐷subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test}) should be consistent.

In summary, we aim to develop a robustness certificate by studying under what condition for {{δi}j=1qi}i=1Rsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑞𝑖𝑖1𝑅\{\{\delta_{i}\}_{j=1}^{q_{i}}\}_{i=1}^{R} that the prediction for a test sample is consistent between the smoothed FL models trained from D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} separately, i.e., hs​(ℳ​(D′);xt​e​s​t)=hs​(ℳ​(D);xt​e​s​t)subscriptℎ𝑠ℳsuperscript𝐷′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscriptℎ𝑠ℳ𝐷subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test})={h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test}). To put forth our certified robustness analysis, we make the following assumptions on the loss function of all clients. Then we present our main theorem and explain its derivation through model closeness and parameter smoothing. Throughout this paper, we denote ∇wℓ​(w;z)subscript∇𝑤ℓ𝑤𝑧\nabla_{w}\ell(w;z) as ∇ℓ​(w;z)∇ℓ𝑤𝑧\nabla\ell(w;z) for simplicity.

Assumption 1 (Convexity and Smoothness).

The loss function ℓ​(w;z)ℓ𝑤𝑧\ell(w;z) is β𝛽\beta-smoothness, i.e, ∀w1,w2for-allsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2\forall w_{1},w_{2},

‖∇ℓ​(w1;z)−∇ℓ​(w2;z)‖≤β​‖w1−w2‖.norm∇ℓsubscript𝑤1𝑧∇ℓsubscript𝑤2𝑧𝛽normsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2\|\nabla\ell(w_{1};z)-\nabla\ell(w_{2};z)\|\leq\beta\|w_{1}-w_{2}\|.

In addition, the loss function ℓ​(w;z)ℓ𝑤𝑧\ell(w;z) is convex. Then co-coercivity of the gradient states:

‖∇ℓ​(w1;z)−∇ℓ​(w2;z)‖2superscriptnorm∇ℓsubscript𝑤1𝑧∇ℓsubscript𝑤2𝑧2\displaystyle\|\nabla\ell(w_{1};z)-\nabla\ell(w_{2};z)\|^{2}
≤β​⟨w1−w2,∇ℓ​(w1;z)−∇ℓ​(w2;z)⟩.absent𝛽subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2∇ℓsubscript𝑤1𝑧∇ℓsubscript𝑤2𝑧\displaystyle\leq\beta\langle w_{1}-w_{2},\nabla\ell(w_{1};z)-\nabla\ell(w_{2};z)\rangle.
Assumption 2 (Lipschitz Gradient w.r.t. Data).

The gradient ∇wl​(z;w)subscript∇𝑤𝑙𝑧𝑤\nabla_{w}l(z;w) is L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} Lipschitz with respect to the argument z𝑧z and norm distance ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|, i.e, ∀z1,z2for-allsubscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2\forall z_{1},z_{2},

‖∇ℓ​(w;z1)−∇ℓ​(w;z2)‖≤L𝒵​‖z1−z2‖.norm∇ℓ𝑤subscript𝑧1∇ℓ𝑤subscript𝑧2subscript𝐿𝒵normsubscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2\|\nabla\ell(w;z_{1})-\nabla\ell(w;z_{2})\|\leq L_{\mathcal{Z}}\|z_{1}-z_{2}\|.
Assumption 3.

The whole FL system follows Algorithm 1 to train and Algorithm 2 to test.

The assumptions on convexity and smoothness are common in the analysis of distributed SGD (Li et al., 2020; Wang & Joshi, 2019). We also make assumption on the Lipschitz gradient w.r.t. data, which is used in (Fallah et al., 2020; Reisizadeh et al., 2020) for analyzing the heterogeneous data distribution across clients.

Main Results

Theorem 1 (General Robustness Condition).

Let hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} be defined as in Eq. 1. When ηi≤1βsubscript𝜂𝑖1𝛽\eta_{i}\leq\frac{1}{\beta} and Assumptions 1, 2, and 3 hold, suppose cA∈𝒴subscript𝑐𝐴𝒴c_{A}\in\mathcal{Y} and pA¯,pB¯∈[0,1]¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵01\underline{p_{A}},\overline{p_{B}}\in[0,1] satisfy

HscA​(ℳ​(D′);xt​e​s​t)≥pA¯≥pB¯≥maxc≠cA⁡Hsc​(ℳ​(D′);xt​e​s​t),superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠subscript𝑐𝐴ℳsuperscript𝐷′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵subscript𝑐subscript𝑐𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐ℳsuperscript𝐷′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{H_{s}^{c_{A}}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test})\geq\underline{p_{A}}\geq\overline{p_{B}}\geq\max_{c\neq c_{A}}{H_{s}^{c}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test}),

then if

R​∑i=1R(pi​γi​τi​ηi​qBinBi​‖δi‖)2𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑞𝐵𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑛𝐵𝑖normsubscript𝛿𝑖2\displaystyle R\sum_{i=1}^{R}(p_{i}\gamma_{i}\tau_{i}\eta_{i}\frac{{{q_{B}}_{i}}}{{{n_{B}}_{i}}}\|\delta_{i}\|)^{2} ≤−log⁡(1−(pA¯−pB¯)2)​σ𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏22​L𝒵2​∏t=𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏+1T(2​Φ​(ρtσt)−1),absent1superscript¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏22superscriptsubscript𝐿𝒵2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏1𝑇2Φsubscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝜎𝑡1\displaystyle\leq\frac{-\log\left(1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}\right)\sigma_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}}^{2}}{2L_{\mathcal{Z}}^{2}\prod\limits_{t=\mathsf{t_{adv}}+1}^{T}\left(2\Phi\left(\frac{\rho_{t}}{\sigma_{t}}\right)-1\right)},

it is guaranteed that

where ΦΦ\Phi is standard Gaussian’s cumulative density function (CDF) and the other parameters are defined in Section 3.

In practice, since the server does not know the global model in the current FL system is poisoned or not, we assume the model is already backdoored and derive the condition when its prediction will be certifiably consistent with the prediction of the clean model. Our certification is on three levels: feature, sample, and client. If the magnitude of the backdoor is upper bounded for every attackers, then we can re-write the Theorem 1 as the following corollary.

then hs​(ℳ​(D′);xt​e​s​t)=hs​(ℳ​(D);xt​e​s​t)=cAsubscriptℎ𝑠ℳsuperscript𝐷′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscriptℎ𝑠ℳ𝐷subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝐴{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test})={h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test})=c_{A} for all ‖δ‖<𝖱𝖠𝖣norm𝛿𝖱𝖠𝖣\|\delta\|<\mathsf{RAD}, where

𝖱𝖠𝖣=−log⁡(1−(pA¯−pB¯)2)​σ𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏22​R​L𝒵2​∑i=1R(pi​γi​τi​ηi​qBinBi)2​∏t=𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏+1T(2​Φ​(ρtσt)−1)𝖱𝖠𝖣1superscript¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏22𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐿𝒵2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑞𝐵𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑛𝐵𝑖2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏1𝑇2Φsubscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝜎𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{RAD}=\sqrt{\frac{-\log\left(1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}\right)\sigma_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}}^{2}}{2RL_{\mathcal{Z}}^{2}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{R}(p_{i}\gamma_{i}\tau_{i}\eta_{i}\frac{{{q_{B}}_{i}}}{{{n_{B}}_{i}}})^{2}\prod\limits_{t=\mathsf{t_{adv}}+1}^{T}\left(2\Phi\left(\frac{\rho_{t}}{\sigma_{t}}\right)-1\right)}} (2)

The function CalculateRadiusCalculateRadius\mathrm{CalculateRadius} in our Algorithm 2 can calculate the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} according to Corollary 1.

We now make several remarks about Corollary 1 and will verify them in our experiments: 1) The noise level σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t} and the parameter norm clipping threshold ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t} are hyper-parameters that can be adjusted to control the robustness-accuracy trade-off. For instance, the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} would be large when: σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t} is high; ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t} is small; the margin between pA¯¯subscript𝑝𝐴\underline{p_{A}} and pB¯¯subscript𝑝𝐵\overline{p_{B}} is large; the number of attackers R𝑅R is small; the poison ratio qBinBisubscriptsubscript𝑞𝐵𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑛𝐵𝑖\frac{{{q_{B}}_{i}}}{{{n_{B}}_{i}}} is small; the scale factor γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i} is small; the aggregation weights for attackers pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is small; the local iteration τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} is small; and the local learning rate ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} small. 2) Since 0≤2​Φ​(⋅)−1≤102Φ⋅110\leq 2\Phi(\cdot)-1\leq 1, the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} goes to ∞\infty as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty when Φ​(⋅)<1Φ⋅1\Phi(\cdot)<1. Ituitively, the benign fine-tuning after backdoor injection round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} would mitegate the poisoning effect. Thus, with infinite rounds of such fine-tuning, the model is able to tolerate backdoors with arbitrarily large magnitude. In practice, we note that the continued multiplication in the denominator may not approach 0 due to numerical issues, which we will verify in the experiments section. 4) Large number of clients N𝑁N will decrease the aggregation weights pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} of attackers, thus it can tolerate backdoors with large magnitude, resulting in higher 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD}. 5) For general neural networks, efficient computation of Lipschitz gradient constant (w.r.t. data input) is an open question, especially when the data dimension is high. We will provide a closed-form expression for L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} under some constraints next.

As mentioned in Section 3.2, the backdoor for data sample zjisuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑗𝑖z_{j}^{i} includes both the backdoor pattern δixsubscript𝛿subscript𝑖𝑥\delta_{i_{x}} and adversarial target label flipping δiysubscript𝛿subscript𝑖𝑦\delta_{i_{y}}. In Assumption 2 we define L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} with z={x,y}𝑧𝑥𝑦z=\{x,y\} (concatenation of x𝑥x and y𝑦y) to certify against both backdoor patterns and label-flipping effects. Without loss of generality, here we focus on backdoor patterns considering bounded model parameters in Lemma 1, which provides a closed-form expression for L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} in the case of multi-class logistic regression. By applying L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} from Lemma 1 to Theorem 1, it indicates that the prediction for a test sample is independent with the backdoor pattern so the backdoor pattern is disentangled from the adversarial target label.

Lemma 1.

Given the upper bound on model parameters norm, i.e., ‖w‖≤ρnorm𝑤𝜌\|w\|\leq\rho, and two data samples z1subscript𝑧1z_{1} and z2subscript𝑧2z_{2} with x1≠x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2x_{1}\neq x_{2} (y1=y2subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2y_{1}=y_{2}), for multi-class logistic regression (i.e., one linear layer followed by a softmax function and trained by cross-entropy loss), its Lipschitz gradient constant w.r.t data is L𝒵=2+2​ρ+ρ2subscript𝐿𝒵22𝜌superscript𝜌2L_{\mathcal{Z}}=\sqrt{2+2\rho+\rho^{2}}. That is,

‖∇ℓ​(w;z1)−∇ℓ​(w;z2)‖≤2+2​ρ+ρ2​‖z1−z2‖.norm∇ℓ𝑤subscript𝑧1∇ℓ𝑤subscript𝑧222𝜌superscript𝜌2normsubscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2\|\nabla\ell(w;z_{1})-\nabla\ell(w;z_{2})\|\leq\sqrt{2+2\rho+\rho^{2}}\|z_{1}-z_{2}\|.

Proof for Lemma 1 is provided in the Appendix B.6.

In order to formally derive the main theorem, there are two key results. We first quantify the closeness between the FL trained models ℳ​(D′)ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) and ℳ(D))\mathcal{M}(D)) using Markov Kernel, and then connect the model closeness to the prediction consistency through parameter smoothing.

5.2 Model Closeness

As described in Algorithm 1, owing to the Gaussian noise perturbation mechanism, in each iteration the global model can be viewed as a random vector with the Gaussian smoothing measure μ𝜇\mu. We use the f-divergence between μ​(ℳ​(D′))𝜇ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) and μ​(ℳ​(D))𝜇ℳ𝐷\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)) as a statistical distance for measuring model closeness of the final FL model. Based on the data post-processing inequality, when we interpret each round of CRFL as a probability transition kernel, i.e., a Markov Kernel, the contraction coefficient of Markov Kernel can help bound the divergence over multiple training rounds of FL.

Let f:(0,∞)→ℝ:𝑓→0ℝf:(0,\infty)\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a convex function with f​(1)=0𝑓10f(1)=0, μ𝜇\mu and ν𝜈\nu be two probability distributions. Then the f-divergence is defined as Df(μ||ν)=EW∼ν[f(μ​(W)ν​(W))].D_{f}(\mu||\nu)=E_{W\sim\nu}[f(\frac{\mu(W)}{\nu(W)})]. Common choices of f-divergence include total variation (f​(x)=12​‖x−1‖𝑓𝑥12norm𝑥1f(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-1\|) and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence (f​(x)=x​log⁡x𝑓𝑥𝑥𝑥f(x)=x\log x). The data processing inequality (Raginsky, 2016; Polyanskiy & Wu, 2015, 2017) for the relative entropy states that, for any convex function f𝑓f and any probability transition kernel (Markov Kernel), Df(μK||νK)≤Df(μ||ν)D_{f}(\mu K||\nu K)\leq D_{f}(\mu||\nu), where μ​K𝜇𝐾\mu K denotes the push-forward of μ𝜇\mu by K𝐾K, i.e., μ​K=∫μ​(d​W)​K​(W)𝜇𝐾𝜇𝑑𝑊𝐾𝑊\mu K=\int\mu(dW)K(W). In other words, Df(μ||ν)D_{f}(\mu||\nu) decreases by post-processing via K𝐾K. (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020) extend it to analyze SGD.

In our setting, all the operations in one round of our CRFL, including SGD, clipping and noise perturbations, are incorporated as a Markov Kernel. We note that in the single-round attack setting, the adversarial clients use clean datasets to train the local models after 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}, so the Markov operator is the same as the one in the benign training process. Therefore the f-divergence of the two global models (backdoored and benign) of interest decreases over rounds, which is characterized by a contraction coefficient defined in Appendix B. We quantify such contraction property of Markov Kernel for each round with the help of two hyperparameters in the server side: model parameter norm clipping threshold ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t} and the noise level σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t}, and finally bound f-divergence of global models in round T𝑇T. Although our analysis can be adopted to general f-divergence, we here use KL divergence as an instantiation to measure the model closeness.

Theorem 2.

When ηi≤1βsubscript𝜂𝑖1𝛽\eta_{i}\leq\frac{1}{\beta} and Assumptions 1, 2, and 3 hold, the KL divergence between μ​(ℳ​(D))𝜇ℳ𝐷\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)) and μ​(ℳ​(D′))𝜇ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) with μ​(w)=𝒩​(w,σT2​𝐈)𝜇𝑤𝒩𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑇2𝐈\mu(w)=\mathcal{N}(w,{\sigma_{T}}^{2}\bf I) is bounded as:

DK​L(μ(ℳ(D))||μ(ℳ(D′)))≤2​R​∑i=1R(pi​γi​τi​ηi​qBinBi​L𝒵​‖δi‖)2σ𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏2​∏t=𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏+1T(2​Φ​(ρtσt)−1)\begin{split}&D_{KL}(\mu(\mathcal{M}(D))||\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})))\\ &\leq\frac{2R\sum_{i=1}^{R}\left(p_{i}\gamma_{i}\tau_{i}\eta_{i}\frac{{{q_{B}}_{i}}}{{{n_{B}}_{i}}}L_{\mathcal{Z}}\|\delta_{i}\|\right)^{2}}{\sigma_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}}^{2}}\prod_{t=\mathsf{t_{adv}}+1}^{T}\left(2\Phi\left(\frac{\rho_{t}}{\sigma_{t}}\right)-1\right)\end{split}

The proof is provided in the Appendix B.

5.3 Parameter Smoothing

We connect the model closeness to the prediction consistency by the following theorem. The smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is robustly certified at μ​(w′)𝜇superscript𝑤′\mu(w^{\prime}) with respect to the bounded KL divergence, DK​L​(μ​(w),μ​(w′))≤ϵsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿𝜇𝑤𝜇superscript𝑤′italic-ϵD_{KL}(\mu(w),\mu(w^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon.

Theorem 3.

Let hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} be defined as in Eq. 1. Suppose cA∈𝒴subscript𝑐𝐴𝒴c_{A}\in\mathcal{Y} and pA¯,pB¯∈[0,1]¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵01\underline{p_{A}},\overline{p_{B}}\in[0,1] satisfy

HscA​(w′;xt​e​s​t)≥pA¯≥pB¯≥maxc≠cA⁡Hsc​(w′;xt​e​s​t),superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠subscript𝑐𝐴superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵subscript𝑐subscript𝑐𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{H_{s}^{c_{A}}}(w^{\prime};x_{test})\geq\underline{p_{A}}\geq\overline{p_{B}}\geq\max_{c\neq c_{A}}{H_{s}^{c}}(w^{\prime};x_{test}),

then hs​(w′;xt​e​s​t)=hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)=cAsubscriptℎ𝑠superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝐴{h_{s}}(w^{\prime};x_{test})={h_{s}}(w;x_{test})=c_{A} for all w𝑤{w} such that DK​L​(μ​(w),μ​(w′))≤ϵsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿𝜇𝑤𝜇superscript𝑤′italic-ϵD_{KL}(\mu(w),\mu(w^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon, where

ϵ=−log⁡(1−(pA¯−pB¯)2)italic-ϵ1superscript¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵2\displaystyle\epsilon=-\log\Big{(}1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}\Big{)}

The proof is provided in the Appendix C.

Finally, combining Theorem 2 and  3 leads to our main Theorem 1. In detail, Theorem 2 states that DK​L(μ(ℳ(D))||μ(ℳ(D′)))D_{KL}(\mu(\mathcal{M}(D))||\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}))) under our CRFL framework is bounded by certain value that depends on the difference between D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}. Theorem 3 states that for a test sample xt​e​s​tsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡x_{test}, as long as the KL divergence is smaller than −log⁡(1−(pA¯−pB¯)2)1superscript¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵2-\log(1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}), the prediction from the poisoned smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} that is built upon the base classifier with model parameter ℳ​(D′)ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) will be consistent with the prediction from hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} that is built upon ℳ​(D)ℳ𝐷\mathcal{M}(D). Therefore, we derive the condition for D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} in Theorem 1, under which DK​L(μ(ℳ(D))||μ(ℳ(D′)))≤−log(1−(pA¯−pB¯)2)D_{KL}(\mu(\mathcal{M}(D))||\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})))\leq-\log(1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}). This condition also indicates that hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} built upon the model parameter ℳ​(D′)ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) is certifiably robust.

Defend against Other Potential Attack

Here we discuss the potentials to generalize our method against other training-time attacks. 1) Our method can naturally extend to fixed-frequency attack by applying our analysis for each attack period. In particular, we can repeatedly apply our Theorem 2 to analyze model closeness for each attack period, and the different initializations of each period can be bounded based on its last period. Then Theorem 3 can be applied to connect model closeness to certify the prediction consistency. 2) (Wang et al., 2020) introduce edge-case adversarial training samples to enforce the model to misclassify inputs on the tail of input distribution. The edge-case attack essentially conducts a special semantic attack (Bagdasaryan et al., 2020) by selecting rare images instead of directly adding backdoor patterns. It is possible to apply our framework against such attack by viewing it as the whole sample manipulation.

Comparison with Differentially Private Federated Learning

In order to protect the privacy of each client, differentially private federated learning (DPFL) mechanisms are proposed (Geyer et al., 2017; McMahan et al., 2018; Agarwal et al., 2018) to ensure that the learned FL model is essentially unchanged when one individual client is modified. Compared with DPFL, our method has several fundamental differences and addresses additional challenges: 1) Mechanisms: DPFL approaches add training-time noise to provide privacy guarantee, while ours add smoothing noise during training and testing to provide certified robustness against data poisoning. In general, the added noise in CRFL does not need to be as large as that in DPFL to provide strong privacy guarantee, and therefore preserve higher model utility. 2) Certification goals: DPFL approaches provide client-level privacy guarantee for the learned model parameters, while in CRFL the robustness guarantee is derived for certified pointwise prediction which could be on the feature, samples and clients levels. 3) Technical contributions: DPFL approaches derive DP guarantee via DP composition theorems (Dwork et al., 2014; Abadi et al., 2016), while we quantify the global model deviation via Markov Kernel and verify the robustness properties of the smoothed model via parameter smoothing.

6 Experiments

In our experiments, the attackers perform the model replacement attack at round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} during our CRFL training, and the server performs parameter smoothing on a possibly backdoored FL model at round T𝑇T to calculate the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} for each test sample based on Corollary 1. Specifically, we evaluate the effect of the training time noise σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t}, the attacker’s ability which includes the number of attackers R𝑅R, the poison ratio qBinBisubscript𝑞subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑛subscript𝐵𝑖\frac{q_{B_{i}}}{n_{B_{i}}} and the scale factor γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i}, robust aggregation protocol, the number of total clients N𝑁N and the number of training rounds T𝑇T. Moreover, we evaluate the model closeness empirically to justify Theorem 2.

6.1 Experiment Setup

We focus on multi-class logistic regression (one linear layer with softmax function and cross-entropy loss), which is a convex classification problem. We train the FL system following our CRFL framework with three datasets: Lending Club Loan Data (LOAN) (Kan, 2019), MNIST (LeCun & Cortes, 2010), and EMNIST (Cohen et al., 2017). We refer the readers to Appendix A for more details about the datasets, parameter setups and attack setting. We train the FL global model until convergence and then use our certification in Algorithm 2 for robustness evaluation.

The metrics of interest are certified rate and certified accuracy. Given a test set of size m𝑚m, for i𝑖i-th test sample, the ground truth label is yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}, and the output prediction is either cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} with the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣isubscript𝖱𝖠𝖣𝑖\mathsf{RAD}_{i} or ci=ABSTAINsubscript𝑐𝑖ABSTAINc_{i}=\texttt{ABSTAIN} with 𝖱𝖠𝖣i=0subscript𝖱𝖠𝖣𝑖0\mathsf{RAD}_{i}=0. Then we calculate certified rate at r𝑟r as 1m​∑i=1m𝟙​{𝖱𝖠𝖣i≥r}1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚double-struck-𝟙subscript𝖱𝖠𝖣𝑖𝑟\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{1}\{\mathsf{RAD}_{i}\geq r\} , and certified accuracy at r𝑟r as 1m∑i=1m𝟙{ci=yi\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{1}\{c_{i}=y_{i} and 𝖱𝖠𝖣i≥r}\mathsf{RAD}_{i}\geq r\}. The certified rate is the fraction of the test set that can be certified at radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣≥r𝖱𝖠𝖣𝑟\mathsf{RAD}\geq r, which reveals how consistent the possibly backdoored classifier’s prediction with the clean classifier’s prediction. The certified accuracy is the fraction of the test set for which the possibly backdoored classifier makes correct and consistent predictions with the clean model. In the displayed figures, there is a critical radius beyond which the certified accuracy and certified rate are dropped to zero. Since each test sample has its own calculated certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣isubscript𝖱𝖠𝖣𝑖\mathsf{RAD}_{i}, this critical value is a threshold that none of them have a larger radius than it, similar to the findings in (Cohen et al., 2019). We certified 10000/5000/10000 samples from the LOAN/MNIST/EMNIST test sets. In all experiments, unless otherwise stated, we use σT=0.01subscript𝜎𝑇0.01\sigma_{T}=0.01 to generate M=1000𝑀1000M=1000 noisy models in parameter smoothing procedure, and use the error tolerance α=0.001𝛼0.001\alpha=0.001. In our experiments, we adopt the expression of L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} in Lemma 1. L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} can be generalized to other poisoning settings by specifying z1,z2subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2z_{1},z_{2} in Assumption 2 under the case of “x1≠x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2x_{1}\neq x_{2} and y1≠y2subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2y_{1}\neq y_{2}” or “x1=x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2x_{1}=x_{2} and y1≠y2subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2y_{1}\neq y_{2}”.

6.2 Experiment Results

We only change one factor in each experiment and keep others the same as the experiment setup. We plot the certified accuracy and certified rate on the clean test set, and report the results on the backdoored test set in Appendix A.

Effect of Training Time Noise

Since we aim to defend against backdoor attack, the training time noise σ𝜎\sigma (σ=σt,t<Tformulae-sequence𝜎subscript𝜎𝑡𝑡𝑇\sigma=\sigma_{t},t<T) in our Algorithm 1 is more essential than σTsubscript𝜎𝑇\sigma_{T} in parameter smoothing (Algorithm 2). The reason is that σ𝜎\sigma can nullify the malicious model updates at early stage. Figure 2 plots the certified accuracy and certified rate attained by training FL system with different σ𝜎\sigma. In Figure 2(a), when σ𝜎\sigma is high, certified rate is high at every r𝑟r and large radius can be certified. Figure 2(b)(c)(d) show that large radius is certified but at a low accuracy, so the parameter noise σ𝜎\sigma controls the trade-off between certifiability and accuracy, which echoes the property of evasion-attack certification (Cohen et al., 2019). Comparing the solid line with the dashed line for each color, we can see that the parameter smoothing with σTsubscript𝜎𝑇\sigma_{T} does not hurt the accuracy much.

Effect of Attacker Ability

From the perspective of attackers, the larger number of attackers R𝑅R, the larger poison ratio qBinBisubscript𝑞subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑛subscript𝐵𝑖\frac{q_{B_{i}}}{n_{B_{i}}} and the larger scale factor γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i} result in the stronger attack. Figure 3, Figure 4, and Figure 5 show that in the three datasets, the stronger the attack, the smaller radius can be certified. After training sufficient number of rounds with clean datasets after 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}, we show that the certified radius is not sensitive to the attack timing 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} in Appendix A.2.

Effect of Robust Aggregation

Our CRFL can be used to assess different robust aggregation rules. Figure 6 presents the certified accuracy on MNIST and EMNIST as R𝑅R is varied, when our CRFL adopts the robust aggregation algorithm RFA (Pillutla et al., 2019), which detects outliers and down-weights the malicious updates during aggregation. Comparing FedAvg in Figure 5 with RFA in Figure 6 (the magnitude of x-axis is different), we observe that very large radius can be certified under RFA. This is because that the attacker is assigned with very low aggregation weights pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}, which is part of our bound in Eq. 2. Our certified radius reveals that RFA is much robust than FedAvg, which shows the potential usage of our certified radius as an evaluation metric for the robustness of other robust aggregation rules.

Effect of Client Number

Distributed learning across a large number of clients is an important property of FL. Figure 7 shows that large radius can be certified when N𝑁N is large (i.e., more clients can tolerant larger backdoor magnitude), because it decreases the aggregation weights pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} of attackers. Moreover, the backdoor effect could be mitigated by more benign model updates during training.

Effect of Training Rounds

According to Figure 8, the certified accuracy is higher when T𝑇T is larger. However, the largest radius that can be certified for the test set does not increase. We note that this is due to numerical issues of the standard Gaussian CDF Φ​(⋅)Φ⋅\Phi(\cdot). As we mentioned in Section 5.1, the continued multiplication in the denominator of Eq. 2 will not achieve 0 in practice. Otherwise the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} goes to ∞\infty as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty since 0≤2​Φ​(ρ/σ)−1≤102Φ𝜌𝜎110\leq 2\Phi(\rho/\sigma)-1\leq 1.

To verify our argument, we fix pA¯¯subscript𝑝𝐴\underline{p_{A}} and pB¯¯subscript𝑝𝐵\overline{p_{B}} to be 0.7 and 0.1, use default values for other parameters, and study the relationship between ρ/σ𝜌𝜎\rho/\sigma, T𝑇T and 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} in Figure 9(b). When ρ/σ𝜌𝜎\rho/\sigma is larger than certain threshold, the certified radius 𝖱𝖠𝖣𝖱𝖠𝖣\mathsf{RAD} does not change much when T𝑇T increases. If one wishes to increase T𝑇T for improving certified radius, then we suggest to keep ρ/σ𝜌𝜎\rho/\sigma smaller than the threshold to make effect. The increased certified accuracy when T𝑇T is large in Figure 8 could be attributed to improved model performance up to convergence, so the margin between pA¯−pB¯¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵\underline{p_{A}}-\overline{p_{B}} is widened.

We also study the error tolerance α𝛼\alpha and the number of noisy models M𝑀M in Appendix A.2. Larger M𝑀M yields larger certified radius, and the certified radius is not very sensitive to α𝛼\alpha.

Empirical Evaluation on Model Closeness

Our theorems are derived based on the analysis in comparison to a “virtual” benign training process. Empirically, we train such FL global model under the benign training process and compare the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distance between the clean global model and the backdoored global model at every round. In Figure 9(a), one attacker performs model replacement attack on MNIST at round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}= {20,40,60}204060\{20,40,60\} respectively. We can observe that the plotted ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distance over the FL training rounds after 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} is decreasing, which echos our assumption that because all clients behave normal and use their clean local datasets to purify the global model after 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}, the global models between two training process become close. This observation also can justify the model closeness statement in Theorem 2.

7 Conclusion

This paper establishes the first framework (CRFL) on certifiably robust federated learning against backdoor attacks. CRFL employs model parameter clipping and perturbing during training, and uses model parameter smoothing during testing, to certify conditions under which a backdoored model will give consistent predictions with an oracle clean model. Our theoretical analysis characterizes the relation between certified robustness and federated learning parameters, which are empirically verified on three different datasets.

Appendix

The Appendix is organized as follows:

  • •

    Appendix A provides more details on experimental setups for training, presents the effect of Monte Carlo estimation and runtime of attacks, and reports the results on backdoored test set.

  • •

    Appendix B provides proofs for our Theorem 2 and Lemma 1 related to model closeness.

  • •

    Appendix C gives proofs for our Theorem 3 related to the parameter smoothing.

Appendix A Experimental Details

A.1 More Details on Experiment Setup for Training

We focus on multi-class logistic regression (one linear layer with softmax function and cross-entropy loss), which is a convex classification problem. We train the FL system following our CRFL framework with three datasets: Lending Club Loan Data (LOAN) (Kan, 2019), MNIST (LeCun & Cortes, 2010), and EMNIST (Cohen et al., 2017). The financial dataset LOAN is a tabular dataset that contains the current loan status (Current, Late, Fully Paid, etc.) and latest payment information, which can be used for loan status prediction. It consists of 1,808,534 data samples and we divide them by 51 US states, each of whom represents a client in FL, hence the data distribution is non-i.i.d. 80% of data samples are used for training and the rest is for testing. EMNIST is an extended MNIST dataset that contains 10 digits and 37 letters. In the two image datasets, we split the training data for FL clients in an i.i.d. manner. The data description and other parameter setups are summarized in Table 1. For these datasets, the local learning rate ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} is 0.001 for all clients. The server performs an adaptive norm clipping threshold ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t} that increases by time so that the normal learning ability of the model can be preserved (described in Table 1), and sets the fixed training noise level σt=0.01subscript𝜎𝑡0.01\sigma_{t}=0.01 (t<T𝑡𝑇t<T). When the clipping threshold is not a fixed value, L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} is calculated based on ρ𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝜌subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\rho_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}} following Lemma 1 for our experiment,.

Regarding the attack setting, by default, we set R=1𝑅1R=1, and if there are more adversarial clients, we use same parameters setups for all of them. For the pixel-pattern backdoor in MNIST and EMNIST, the attackers add the backdoor pattern (see Figure. 10 for an example) in images and swap the label of any sample with such patterns into the target label, which is “digit 0”. Similarly, for the preprocessed111We preprocess LOAN by dropping the features which are not digital and cannot be one-hot encoded, and then normalizing the rest 90 features and so that the value of each feature is between 0 and 1. LOAN dataset, the attackers increase the value of the two features (i.e., num_tl_120dpd_2m, num_tl_90g_dpd_24m) as a backdoor pattern, and swap label to “Does not meet the credit policy. Status:Fully Paid”. Since we adopt Lemma 1 for our experiments, we focus on the backdoor pattern ‖δi‖=‖δix‖normsubscript𝛿𝑖normsubscript𝛿subscript𝑖𝑥\|\delta_{i}\|=\|\delta_{i_{x}}\|. The magnitude of backdoored pattern in every example is ‖δi‖=0.1normsubscript𝛿𝑖0.1\|\delta_{i}\|=0.1 on three datasets. Every attacker’s batch is mixed with correctly labeled data and such backdoored data with poison ratio qBi/nBisubscript𝑞subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑛subscript𝐵𝑖q_{B_{i}}/n_{B_{i}}.

We train the FL global model until convergence and then use our certification in Algorithm 2 for robustness evaluation.

A.2 More Experimental Results on Clean Test Set

Effect of Monte Carlo estimation

Recall that we use M𝑀M and α𝛼\alpha when calculating the lower bound pA¯¯subscript𝑝𝐴\underline{p_{A}} and the upper bound pB¯¯subscript𝑝𝐵\overline{p_{B}}. Figure 11 (left) shows that larger number M𝑀M of noisy models used for certification can result in larger certified radius. Figure 11 (middle) presents that the certified radius is smaller when the error tolerance α𝛼\alpha is smaller but overall the certified accuracy is not very sensitive to α𝛼\alpha.

Effect of Attack Timing 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}

For Figure 11 (right), we use a strong attack (γ𝛾\gamma=100, R𝑅R=2) and report the certified accuracy with different 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}. As described in Table 1, ρ𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝜌subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\rho_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}} increases with 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}, and L𝒵subscript𝐿𝒵L_{\mathcal{Z}} is calculated based on ρ𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝜌subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\rho_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}}. In order to control variable, we use the same, loose Lzsubscript𝐿𝑧L_{z} which is calculated based on ρ44subscript𝜌44\rho_{44} for all 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏=10,20,40,43,44subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏1020404344\mathsf{t_{adv}}=10,20,40,43,44. The results show that the certified radius is not sensitive to the attack timing 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} after training sufficient number of rounds with clean datasets after 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}.

A.3 Experimental Results on Backdoored Test Set

In this section, we report the certified accuracy on the backdoored test set. For every test sample, the backdoor pattern is added to the input while the label is still correct. As shown in Figure 12 and 13, the results are similar to the results on the clean test set.

Appendix B Proofs of Model Closeness

In this section, we will present preliminaries on f-divergence, define the problem of model closeness and then provide the detailed proofs for our Theorem  2 and Lemma  1 that are related to model closeness. Let us list the notations used in the paper and the Appendix in Table 2.

Throughout this paper, “benign training process” is the process that trains with clean dataset D𝐷D for T𝑇T rounds and outputs ℳ​(D)ℳ𝐷\mathcal{M}(D); “backdoored training process” is the process that trains with poisoned dataset D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} at round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}, trains with original clean dataset when t≠𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏𝑡subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏t\neq\mathsf{t_{adv}}, and outputs ℳ​(D′)ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}).

B.1 Preliminaries on f-divergence

Let f:(0,∞)→ℝ:𝑓→0ℝf:(0,\infty)\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a convex function with f​(1)=0𝑓10f(1)=0, ν𝜈\nu and ρ𝜌\rho be two probability distributions. Then f-divergence is defined as

Df(ν||ρ)=EW∼ρ[f(ν​(W)ρ​(W))].D_{f}(\nu||\rho)=E_{W\sim\rho}\left[f(\frac{\nu(W)}{\rho(W)})\right]. (3)

Common f-divergence includes Total variation f​(x)=12​‖x−1‖𝑓𝑥12norm𝑥1f(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-1\| and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence f​(x)=x​log⁡x𝑓𝑥𝑥𝑥f(x)=x\log x.

Lemma 2.

For m1,m2∈ℝdsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2superscriptℝ𝑑m_{1},m_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and σ>0𝜎0\sigma\textgreater 0, let 𝒩1subscript𝒩1\mathcal{N}_{1}and 𝒩2subscript𝒩2\mathcal{N}_{2} denote Gaussian distribution 𝒩1​(m1,σ2​I)subscript𝒩1subscript𝑚1superscript𝜎2𝐼\mathcal{N}_{1}(m_{1},\sigma^{2}I) and 𝒩2​(m2,σ2​I)subscript𝒩2subscript𝑚2superscript𝜎2𝐼\mathcal{N}_{2}(m_{2},\sigma^{2}I), respectively. Then,

DK​L(𝒩1||𝒩2)=‖m2−m1‖22​σ2,\displaystyle D_{KL}(\mathcal{N}_{1}||\mathcal{N}_{2})=\frac{\|m_{2}-m_{1}\|^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}, (4)
DT​V(𝒩1||𝒩2)=2Φ(‖m2−m1‖σ)−1,\displaystyle D_{TV}(\mathcal{N}_{1}||\mathcal{N}_{2})=2\Phi\left(\frac{\|m_{2}-m_{1}\|}{\sigma}\right)-1, (5)

where ΦΦ\Phi is the CDF of the Gaussian distribution.

The well-known data processing inequality (Polyanskiy & Wu, 2015) for the relative entropy states that, for any convex function f𝑓f and any stochastic transformation (probability transition kernel), i.e., Markov Kernel K𝐾K, we have

Df(νK||ρK)≤Df(ν||ρ),D_{f}(\nu K||\rho K)\leq D_{f}(\nu||\rho),

where ν​K𝜈𝐾\nu K denotes the push-forward of ν𝜈\nu by K𝐾K, i.e., ν​K=∫ν​(d​W)​K​(W)𝜈𝐾𝜈𝑑𝑊𝐾𝑊\nu K=\int\nu(dW)K(W). In other words, Df(ν||ρ)D_{f}(\nu||\rho) decreases by post-processing. (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020) extends it into machine learning and the operations in a Markov Kernel contain one step of Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD).

To capture this effect, the quantity of the noisiness of a Markov operator (Raginsky, 2016) for f-divergence, i.e., contraction coefficient (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020), is defined as

ηf​(K):=supν,ρ;Df(ν||ρ)≠0Df(νK||ρK)Df(ν||ρ).\eta_{f}(K):=\sup\limits_{\nu,\rho;{D_{f}(\nu||\rho)\neq 0}}\frac{D_{f}(\nu K||\rho K)}{D_{f}(\nu||\rho)}. (6)
Lemma 3 (Two-point characterization of Total variation (Dobrushin, 1956)).

The supremum in the definition of ηT​V​(K)subscript𝜂𝑇𝑉𝐾\eta_{TV}(K) can be restricted to point mass:

ηT​V(K):=supy1,y2∈yDT​V(K(y1)||K(y2))\eta_{TV}(K):=\sup\limits_{y_{1},y_{2}\in y}D_{TV}(K(y_{1})||K(y_{2})) (7)
Lemma 4 (ηT​V​(K)subscript𝜂𝑇𝑉𝐾\eta_{TV}(K) Upper Bound (Makur, 2019)).

For any f-divergence, we have

ηf​(K)≤ηT​V​(K)subscript𝜂𝑓𝐾subscript𝜂𝑇𝑉𝐾\eta_{f}(K)\leq\eta_{TV}(K) (8)

B.2 Problem Definition

As described in Algorithm 1, due to the Gaussian noise perturbation mechanism, in each iteration the global model can be viewed as a random vector with the Gaussian smoothing measure μ𝜇\mu. We use the f-divergence between μ​(ℳ​(D′))𝜇ℳsuperscript𝐷′\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) and μ​(ℳ​(D))𝜇ℳ𝐷\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)) as a statistical distance for measuring model closeness. According to the data post-processing inequality, when we interpret each round of CRFL as a probability transition kernel, i.e., a Markov Kernel, the contraction coefficient of Markov Kernel can help bound the divergence over multiple training rounds of FL.

Iteration as Markov Kernel

We identify each iteration as a Markov Kernel. After Model Replacement Attack

After 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}}, all clients use the original clean datasets to update their local model. However, the global model in the backdoored training process already begins to differ from the one in the benign training process from round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} so it is difficult to analysis it through distributed SGD. Therefore, we use Markov Kernel to quantify the poisoning effect. When t>𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏𝑡subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏t\textgreater\mathsf{t_{adv}}, we have w~t−1′∼μt−1′similar-tosubscriptsuperscript~𝑤′𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜇′𝑡1\widetilde{w}^{\prime}_{t-1}\sim\mu^{\prime}_{t-1}, then μt′=∫μt−1′​(d​y)​Kt​(y).subscriptsuperscript𝜇′𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜇′𝑡1𝑑𝑦subscript𝐾𝑡𝑦\mu^{\prime}_{t}=\int\mu^{\prime}_{t-1}(dy)K_{t}(y). Because the clean datasets are used for both clean and backdoored training process when t>𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏𝑡subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏t\textgreater\mathsf{t_{adv}}, the Markov Kernel Ktsubscript𝐾𝑡K_{t} is the same. We define the contraction coefficient (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020) as:

ηf​(Kt):=supμt−1,μt−1′;Df​(μt−1∥μt−1′)≠0Df​(μt−1​Kt∥μt−1′​Kt)Df​(μt−1∥μt−1′).\eta_{f}(K_{t}):=\sup\limits_{\mu_{t-1},\mu^{\prime}_{t-1};\atop{D_{f}(\mu_{t-1}\|\mu^{\prime}_{t-1})\neq 0}}\frac{D_{f}(\mu_{t-1}K_{t}\|\mu^{\prime}_{t-1}K_{t})}{D_{f}(\mu_{t-1}\|\mu^{\prime}_{t-1})}. (12)

Lemma 6 states that the deviation is accumulated over the local iterations. The larger number of local iterations τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}, the larger deviation ΔτiisuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖\Delta_{{\tau_{i}}}^{i}. Next, we provide the upper bound for ‖ℬi‖normsuperscriptℬ𝑖\|\mathcal{B}^{i}\|.

Scaling and Aggregation

Let the scale factor be γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i} for i𝑖i-th adversarial client, then the scaled malicious local update is γi​(w′𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏​τii−w~𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏−1).subscript𝛾𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑤′subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝜏𝑖𝑖subscript~𝑤subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏1\gamma_{i}({w^{\prime}}_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}\tau_{i}}^{i}-\widetilde{w}_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}-1}). We assume in the benign setting (which is a virtual training process for analyzing, and we do not really train such model), this client also scales its clean local updates as γi​(w𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏​τii−w~𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏−1),subscript𝛾𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝜏𝑖𝑖subscript~𝑤subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏1\gamma_{i}({w}_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}\tau_{i}}^{i}-\widetilde{w}_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}-1}), which can be expanded as −ηi​γi​∑s=(𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏−1)​τi+1𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏​τigi​(ws−1i;ξs−1i).subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝛾𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏1subscript𝜏𝑖1subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑠1𝑖-\eta_{i}\gamma_{i}\sum_{s=(\mathsf{t_{adv}}-1)\tau_{i}+1}^{\mathsf{t_{adv}}\tau_{i}}g_{i}\left(w_{s-1}^{i};\xi_{s-1}^{i}\right). This assumption does not hurt the global model performance in the virtual benign setting since the local learning objectives are benign so scaling the updates is equivalent to scale its local learning rate ηi←ηi​γi←subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝛾𝑖\eta_{i}\leftarrow\eta_{i}\gamma_{i}.

After aggregation, the deviation between global model parameters in benign and backdoored training process can be bounded. Note that the benign local model updates are cancelled out since they are the same in the two training process.

Lemma 8.

The deviation between the aggregated global model in the benign training process and the global model in the backdoored training process at round 𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏subscript𝗍𝖺𝖽𝗏\mathsf{t_{adv}} is

B.6 Proof of Lemma 1

We first restate our Lemma 1 here and then provide the detailed proof. See 1

Proof.

Appendix C Proofs of Parameter Smoothing

In this section, we explain our parameter smoothing for general f-divergence, and give closed-form certification for KL divergence, which corresponds to the proofs for our Theorems 3.

C.1 General Framework for Robustness Certification

Consider a classifier h:(𝒲,𝒳)→𝒴:ℎ→𝒲𝒳𝒴h:\mathcal{(W,X)}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}. The output of the classifier depends on both the test input and its model parameters (i.e., model weights) of this classifier. In the testing phase, the model weight w𝑤w is fixed, just like xt​e​s​tsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡x_{test}, so it can be seen as an argument for the classifier hℎh. For example, in a one-linear-layer model, h​(w;xt​e​s​t)=softmax​(w×xt​e​s​t)ℎ𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡softmax𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡h(w;x_{test})=\mathrm{softmax}(w\times x_{test}), where ×\times is the multiplication operation; in a one-conv-layer model, h​(w;xt​e​s​t)=softmax​(w⊛xt​e​s​t)ℎ𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡softmax⊛𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡h(w;x_{test})=\mathrm{softmax}(w\circledast x_{test}) where ⊛⊛\circledast is the convolution operation. In a model with multiple layers, the expression of model prediction h​(w;xt​e​s​t)ℎ𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡h(w;x_{test}) also holds, where w𝑤w consists of the weights from all layers. To our best knowledge, this is the first work to study parameter smoothing on w𝑤w rather than input smoothing on xt​e​s​tsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡x_{test}.

We want to verify the robustness of smoothed multi-class classifier. Recall that we smooth the classifier h:(𝒲,𝒳)→𝒴:ℎ→𝒲𝒳𝒴h:\mathcal{(W,X)}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} with finite set of label 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} using a smoothing measure μ:𝒲↦𝒫​(𝒲):𝜇maps-to𝒲𝒫𝒲\mu:\mathcal{W}\mapsto\mathcal{P(W)}. The resulting randomly smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is

hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)=arg⁡maxc∈𝒴⁡ℙW∼μ​(w)​[h​(W;xt​e​s​t)=c]subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝒴subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜇𝑤delimited-[]ℎ𝑊subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐h_{s}(w;x_{test})=\arg\max_{c\in\mathcal{Y}}\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\mu(w)}[h(W;x_{test})=c] (27)

Our goal is to certify that the prediction hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡h_{s}(w;x_{test}) is robust to model parameters perturbations of size at most ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon measured by some distance function d𝑑d, i.e.,

hs​(w′;xt​e​s​t)=hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)​ ∀w′ such that d​(w,w′)≤ϵsubscriptℎ𝑠superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡 ∀w′ such that d(w,w′)≤ϵh_{s}(w^{\prime};x_{test})=h_{s}(w;x_{test})\text{ $\forall{w^{\prime}}$ such that $d(w,w^{\prime})\leq\epsilon$} (28)

We assume 𝒲⊆ℝd𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{W}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d} (a d𝑑d dimensional model parameters space). Our framework involves a reference measure ρ=μ​(w)𝜌𝜇𝑤\rho=\mu(w), the set of perturbed distributions 𝒟w,ϵ={μ​(w′):d​(w,w′)≤ϵ}subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵconditional-set𝜇superscript𝑤′𝑑𝑤superscript𝑤′italic-ϵ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}=\{\mu(w^{\prime}):d(w,w^{\prime})\leq\epsilon\}, and a set of specifications ϕ:(𝒲,𝒳)→𝒵⊆ℝ:italic-ϕ→𝒲𝒳𝒵ℝ\phi:\mathcal{(W,X)}\rightarrow\mathcal{Z}\subseteq\mathbb{R}. Specifically, let c=hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)𝑐subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡c=h_{s}(w;x_{test}). Since we are working on the multi-class classification problem, for every pair of classes {c,c′}𝑐superscript𝑐′\{c,c^{\prime}\} where c′∈𝒴∖{c}superscript𝑐′𝒴𝑐c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}\setminus\{c\}, we need a ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, which is a generic function over the model parameters space that we want to verify has robustness properties. Following (Dvijotham et al., 2020), for every c′∈𝒴∖{c}superscript𝑐′𝒴𝑐c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}\setminus\{c\}, we define a specification ϕc,c′:(𝒲,𝒳)↦{−1,0,+1}:subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′maps-to𝒲𝒳101\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}:\mathcal{(W,X)}\mapsto\{-1,0,+1\} as follows:

ϕc,c′​(w)={+1if h​(w;xt​e​s​t)=c−1if h​(w;xt​e​s​t)=c′0otherwisesubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′𝑤cases1if h(w;xtest)=c1if h(w;xtest)=c′0otherwise\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}(w)=\begin{cases}+1&\text{if $h(w;x_{test})=c$}\\ -1&\text{if $h(w;x_{test})=c^{\prime}$}\\ 0&\text{otherwise}\end{cases} (29)

where we denote ϕc,c′​(w;xt​e​s​t)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}(w;x_{test}) as ϕc,c′​(w)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′𝑤\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}(w) for simplicity.

Proposition 1.

The smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is robustly certified, i.e., Eq. 28 holds, if and only if for every c′∈𝒴∖{c}superscript𝑐′𝒴𝑐c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}\setminus\{c\}, ϕc,c′subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′\phi_{c,c^{\prime}} is robustly certified at μ​(w)𝜇𝑤\mu(w) w.r.t 𝒟w,ϵsubscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}. Verifying that a given specification ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is robustly certified is equivalent to checking if the optimal value of the following optimization problem is non-negative:

O​P​T​(ϕ,ρ,𝒟w,ϵ):=minν∈𝒟w,ϵ⁡𝔼W′∼ν​(ϕ​(W′))assign𝑂𝑃𝑇italic-ϕ𝜌subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵsubscript𝜈subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵsubscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈italic-ϕsuperscript𝑊′OPT(\phi,\rho,\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}):=\min_{\nu\in\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}}\mathbb{E}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}(\phi(W^{\prime})) (30)
Proof.

Note that for any perturbed distribution ν∈𝒟w,ϵ𝜈subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵ\nu\in\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}, according to the definition of expectation and Eq. 29, we have

𝔼W′∼ν​[ϕc,c′​(W′)]=ℙW′∼ν​[h​(W′;xt​e​s​t)=c]−ℙW′∼ν​[h​(W′;xt​e​s​t)=c′].subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝑊′subscriptℙsimilar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]ℎsuperscript𝑊′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐subscriptℙsimilar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]ℎsuperscript𝑊′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡superscript𝑐′\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}(W^{\prime})]=\mathbb{P}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[h(W^{\prime};x_{test})=c]-\mathbb{P}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[h(W^{\prime};x_{test})=c^{\prime}]. (31)

Therefore, 𝔼W′∼ν​[ϕc,c′​(W′)]≥0subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝑊′0\mathbb{E}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}(W^{\prime})]\geq 0 for all c′∈𝒴∖{c}superscript𝑐′𝒴𝑐c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}\setminus\{c\} is equivalent to c=arg⁡maxy∈𝒞⁡ℙW′∼ν​[h​(W′;xt​e​s​t)=y]𝑐subscript𝑦𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]ℎsuperscript𝑊′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑦c=\arg\max_{y\in\mathcal{C}}\mathbb{P}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[h(W^{\prime};x_{test})=y]. For ν=μ​(w′)𝜈𝜇superscript𝑤′\nu=\mu(w^{\prime}), this means that hs​(w′;xt​e​s​t)=csubscriptℎ𝑠superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐h_{s}(w^{\prime};x_{test})=c. In other words, 𝔼W′∼ν​[ϕc,c′​(W′)]≥0subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝑊′0\mathbb{E}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[\phi_{c,c^{\prime}}(W^{\prime})]\geq 0 for all c′∈𝒴∖{c}superscript𝑐′𝒴𝑐c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}\setminus\{c\} and all ν=μ​(w′)⊂𝒟w,ϵ𝜈𝜇superscript𝑤′subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵ\nu=\mu(w^{\prime})\subset\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon} if and only if hs​(w′;xt​e​s​t)=csubscriptℎ𝑠superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐h_{s}(w^{\prime};x_{test})=c for all w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} such that d​(w,w′)≤ϵ𝑑𝑤superscript𝑤′italic-ϵd(w,w^{\prime})\leq\epsilon, proving the required robustness certificate. ∎

Then we define the certification problem 222It is called information-limited robust certification in (Dvijotham et al., 2020) for input smoothing.:

Definition 1.

Given a reference distribution ρ∈𝒫​(𝒲)𝜌𝒫𝒲\rho\in\mathcal{P(W)}, probabilities pAsubscript𝑝𝐴p_{A} ,pBsubscript𝑝𝐵p_{B} that satisfy pA,pB≥0subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵0p_{A},p_{B}\geq 0, pA+pB≤1subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵1p_{A}+p_{B}\leq 1, we define the class of specifications S𝑆S:

S={ϕ:(𝒲,𝒳)↦{−1,0,+1}​ s.t. ​ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=+1]≥pA,ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=−1]≤pB}𝑆conditional-setitalic-ϕformulae-sequencemaps-to𝒲𝒳101 s.t. subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊1subscript𝑝𝐴subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊1subscript𝑝𝐵S=\{\phi:\mathcal{(W,X)}\mapsto\{-1,0,+1\}\text{ s.t. }\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=+1]\geq p_{A},\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=-1]\leq p_{B}\} (32)

Given the above definition of S𝑆S, we can rewrite Proposition 1 as:

Proposition 2.

The smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is robustly certified, i.e., Eq. 28 holds, if and only if S𝑆S is robustly certified at μ​(w)𝜇𝑤\mu(w) w.r.t 𝒟w,ϵsubscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}. Verifying that S𝑆S is robustly certified is equivalent to checking if the condition 𝔼W′∼ν​[ϕ​(W′)]≥0subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑊′𝜈delimited-[]italic-ϕsuperscript𝑊′0\mathbb{E}_{W^{\prime}\sim\nu}[\phi(W^{\prime})]\geq 0 holds for all ν∈𝒟w,ϵ𝜈subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵ\nu\in\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon} and ϕ∈Sitalic-ϕ𝑆\phi\in S.

We need to provide guarantees that hold simultaneously over a whole class of specifications (ϕc,c′subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐superscript𝑐′\phi_{c,c^{\prime}} for all c′∈𝒴∖{c}superscript𝑐′𝒴𝑐c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}\setminus\{c\} ). In fact, pAsubscript𝑝𝐴p_{A} can be the seen as the “votes” for the top-one class c𝑐c, and pBsubscript𝑝𝐵p_{B} can be seen as the “votes” for the runner-up class. We note that the function f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) used in f-divergence is convex. As shown in (Dvijotham et al., 2020) (but for input smoothing), for perturbation sets 𝒟w,ϵ={μ​(w′):d​(w,w′)≤ϵ}={ν:Df​(ν∥μ​(w))≤ϵ}subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵconditional-set𝜇superscript𝑤′𝑑𝑤superscript𝑤′italic-ϵconditional-set𝜈subscript𝐷𝑓conditional𝜈𝜇𝑤italic-ϵ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}=\{\mu(w^{\prime}):d(w,w^{\prime})\leq\epsilon\}=\{\nu:D_{f}(\nu\|\mu(w))\leq\epsilon\} specified by a f-divergence Dfsubscript𝐷𝑓D_{f} bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, this certification task can be solved efficiently using convex optimization.

Theorem 4.

The smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is robustly certified at reference distribution ρ𝜌\rho with respect to 𝒟w,ϵ={ν:Df​(ν∥ρ)≤ϵ}subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵconditional-set𝜈subscript𝐷𝑓conditional𝜈𝜌italic-ϵ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}=\{\nu:D_{f}(\nu\|\rho)\leq\epsilon\} if and only if the optimal value of the following convex optimization problem is non-negative:

maxλ≥0,κ⁡κ−λ​ϵ−pA​fλ∗​(κ−1)−pB​fλ∗​(κ+1)−(1−pA−pB)​fλ∗​(κ)≥0subscript𝜆0𝜅𝜅𝜆italic-ϵsubscript𝑝𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑓𝜆𝜅1subscript𝑝𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑓𝜆𝜅11subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑓𝜆𝜅0\displaystyle\max_{\lambda\geq 0,\kappa}\kappa-\lambda\epsilon-p_{A}f_{\lambda}^{*}(\kappa-1)-p_{B}f_{\lambda}^{*}(\kappa+1)-(1-p_{A}-p_{B})f_{\lambda}^{*}(\kappa)\geq 0 (33)

We prove the theorem according to Proposition 2. Let ρ​(W)𝜌𝑊\rho(W) be the clean model parameters distribution, ν​(W)𝜈𝑊\nu(W) be the perturbed model parameters distribution, r​(W)=ν​(W)ρ​(W)𝑟𝑊𝜈𝑊𝜌𝑊r(W)=\frac{\nu(W)}{\rho(W)} be likelihood ratio. We have

𝔼W∼ν​[ϕ​(W)]subscript𝔼similar-to𝑊𝜈delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{W\sim\nu}[\phi(W)] =𝔼W∼ρ​[r​(W)​ϕ​(W)],absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]𝑟𝑊italic-ϕ𝑊\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{W\sim\rho}[r(W)\phi(W)], (34)

where pA=ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=+1]subscript𝑝𝐴subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊1p_{A}=\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=+1], pB=ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=−1]subscript𝑝𝐵subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊1p_{B}=\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=-1], 1−pA−pB=ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=0]1subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊01-p_{A}-p_{B}=\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=0], ∎

Remark.

Note that our differences from (Dvijotham et al., 2020) are in two aspects: (1) Our certification is with respect to the smoothing scheme on model parameters W𝑊W; (2) We concretize the corresponding Theorem 2 in (Dvijotham et al., 2020) by the explicit constraints on pAsubscript𝑝𝐴p_{A}, pBsubscript𝑝𝐵p_{B}.

C.2 Closed-form Certificate for KL Divergence

We instantize Theorem 4 with KL divergence.

Lemma 12.

Let DK​Lsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿D_{KL} be the KL divergence, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon be the divergence constraint, S𝑆S, pA,pBsubscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵p_{A},p_{B} be as in Definition 1. The smoothed classifier hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} is robustly certified at reference distribution ρ𝜌\rho with respect to 𝒟w,ϵ={ν:DK​L​(ν∥ρ)≤ϵ}subscript𝒟𝑤italic-ϵconditional-set𝜈subscript𝐷𝐾𝐿conditional𝜈𝜌italic-ϵ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}=\{\nu:D_{KL}(\nu\|\rho)\leq\epsilon\} if and only if:

ϵ≤−log⁡(1−(pA−pB)2)italic-ϵ1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵2\displaystyle\epsilon\leq-\log\Big{(}1-(\sqrt{p_{A}}-\sqrt{p_{B}})^{2}\Big{)} (39)
Proof for Lemma 12.

The function f​(u)=u​l​o​g​(u)𝑓𝑢𝑢𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑢f(u)=ulog(u) for KL divergence is a convex function with f​(1)=0𝑓10f(1)=0 , then we have

fλ∗​(u)=maxv≥0⁡(u​v−λ​f​(v))=maxv≥0⁡(u​v−λ​v​log⁡(v)).superscriptsubscript𝑓𝜆𝑢subscript𝑣0𝑢𝑣𝜆𝑓𝑣subscript𝑣0𝑢𝑣𝜆𝑣𝑣f_{\lambda}^{*}(u)=\max_{v\geq 0}(uv-\lambda f(v))=\max_{v\geq 0}(uv-\lambda v\log(v)).

Setting the derivative with respect to v𝑣v to 0 and solving for v𝑣v, we obtain v=exp⁡(u−λλ),λ>0formulae-sequence𝑣𝑢𝜆𝜆𝜆0v=\exp\left(\frac{u-\lambda}{\lambda}\right),\lambda\textgreater 0. So we have

fλ∗​(u)=λ​exp⁡(uλ−1).superscriptsubscript𝑓𝜆𝑢𝜆𝑢𝜆1f_{\lambda}^{*}(u)=\lambda\exp\left(\frac{u}{\lambda}-1\right). (40)

Suppose we have a bound on the KL divergence Df​(ν∥ρ)≤ϵsubscript𝐷𝑓conditional𝜈𝜌italic-ϵD_{f}(\nu\|\rho)\leq\epsilon, then we want that the optimal certificate is non-negative:

maxλ>0,κ⁡(κ−λ​ϵ−pA​λ​exp⁡(κ−1λ−1)−pB​λ​exp⁡(κ+1λ−1)−(1−pA−pB)​λ​exp⁡(κλ−1))≥0.subscript𝜆0𝜅𝜅𝜆italic-ϵsubscript𝑝𝐴𝜆𝜅1𝜆1subscript𝑝𝐵𝜆𝜅1𝜆11subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵𝜆𝜅𝜆10\displaystyle\max_{\lambda\textgreater 0,\kappa}\Bigg{(}\kappa-\lambda\epsilon-p_{A}\lambda\exp\left(\frac{\kappa-1}{\lambda}-1\right)-p_{B}\lambda\exp\left(\frac{\kappa+1}{\lambda}-1\right)-(1-p_{A}-p_{B})\lambda\exp\left(\frac{\kappa}{\lambda}-1\right)\Bigg{)}\geq 0. (41)

Setting y=κ/λ,z=1λ​(z>0)formulae-sequence𝑦𝜅𝜆𝑧1𝜆𝑧0y=\kappa/\lambda,z=\frac{1}{\lambda}(z\textgreater 0), we can rewrite Eq. 41 as:

maxz>0,y⁡(1z​(y−ϵ−pA​exp⁡(y−z−1)−pB​exp⁡(y+z−1)−(1−pA−pB)​exp⁡(y−1)))≥0.subscript𝑧0𝑦1𝑧𝑦italic-ϵsubscript𝑝𝐴𝑦𝑧1subscript𝑝𝐵𝑦𝑧11subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵𝑦10\displaystyle\max_{z\textgreater 0,y}\Bigg{(}\frac{1}{z}\Big{(}y-\epsilon-p_{A}\exp(y-z-1)-p_{B}\exp(y+z-1)-(1-p_{A}-p_{B})\exp(y-1)\Big{)}\Bigg{)}\geq 0. (42)

Because 1z1𝑧\frac{1}{z} is positive, we divide both the LHS and RHS by 1z1𝑧\frac{1}{z} and our goal can be rewritten as:

maxz>0,y⁡(y−ϵ−pA​exp⁡(y−z−1)−pB​exp⁡(y+z−1)−(1−pA−pB)​exp⁡(y−1))≥0.subscript𝑧0𝑦𝑦italic-ϵsubscript𝑝𝐴𝑦𝑧1subscript𝑝𝐵𝑦𝑧11subscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵𝑦10\displaystyle\max_{z\textgreater 0,y}\Bigg{(}y-\epsilon-p_{A}\exp(y-z-1)-p_{B}\exp(y+z-1)-(1-p_{A}-p_{B})\exp(y-1)\Bigg{)}\geq 0. (43)

pA​exp⁡(y−z−1)−pB​exp⁡(y+z−1)subscript𝑝𝐴𝑦𝑧1subscript𝑝𝐵𝑦𝑧1\displaystyle p_{A}\exp(y-z-1)-p_{B}\exp(y+z-1) =0absent0\displaystyle=0 (44)

maxy⁡(y−ϵ−(1−(pA−pB)2)​exp⁡(y−1)).subscript𝑦𝑦italic-ϵ1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵2𝑦1\displaystyle\max_{y}\Bigg{(}y-\epsilon-\Big{(}1-(\sqrt{p_{A}}-\sqrt{p_{B}})^{2}\Big{)}\exp(y-1)\Bigg{)}. (45)

1−(1−(pA−pB)2)​exp⁡(y−1)11superscriptsubscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵2𝑦1\displaystyle 1-\Big{(}1-(\sqrt{p_{A}}-\sqrt{p_{B}})^{2}\Big{)}\exp(y-1) =0absent0\displaystyle=0 (46)

For this number to be positive, we need

ϵ≤−log⁡(1−(pA−pB)2).italic-ϵ1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝐴subscript𝑝𝐵2\displaystyle\epsilon\leq-\log\Big{(}1-(\sqrt{p_{A}}-\sqrt{p_{B}})^{2}\Big{)}. (48)

Hence, proved. ∎

Remark.

The challenges are: 1) we divide both the LHS and RHS of Eq. 42 by 1z1𝑧\frac{1}{z} to obtain Eq. 43, otherwise the derivative of the LHS of Eq. 42 cannot be calculated directly. Moreover, setting y=κ/λ,z=1λformulae-sequence𝑦𝜅𝜆𝑧1𝜆y=\kappa/\lambda,z=\frac{1}{\lambda} makes it much easier to solve the optimization problem. 2) (Dvijotham et al., 2020) does not directly provide proof for KL Divergence. They prove the certification for Renyi Divergence and then regard KL as a special case of Renyi Divergence.

Finally, we restate our Theorem  3 here.

Theorem 3.

Let hssubscriptℎ𝑠h_{s} be defined as in Eq. 1. Suppose cA∈𝒴subscript𝑐𝐴𝒴c_{A}\in\mathcal{Y} and pA¯,pB¯∈[0,1]¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵01\underline{p_{A}},\overline{p_{B}}\in[0,1] satisfy

HscA​(w′;xt​e​s​t)≥pA¯≥pB¯≥maxc≠cA⁡Hsc​(w′;xt​e​s​t),superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠subscript𝑐𝐴superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵subscript𝑐subscript𝑐𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{H_{s}^{c_{A}}}(w^{\prime};x_{test})\geq\underline{p_{A}}\geq\overline{p_{B}}\geq\max_{c\neq c_{A}}{H_{s}^{c}}(w^{\prime};x_{test}),

then hs​(w′;xt​e​s​t)=hs​(w;xt​e​s​t)=cAsubscriptℎ𝑠superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscriptℎ𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝐴{h_{s}}(w^{\prime};x_{test})={h_{s}}(w;x_{test})=c_{A} for all w𝑤{w} such that DK​L​(μ​(w),μ​(w′))≤ϵsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿𝜇𝑤𝜇superscript𝑤′italic-ϵD_{KL}(\mu(w),\mu(w^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon, where

ϵ=−log⁡(1−(pA¯−pB¯)2)italic-ϵ1superscript¯subscript𝑝𝐴¯subscript𝑝𝐵2\displaystyle\epsilon=-\log\Big{(}1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}\Big{)}
Proof.

We use Lemma 12 to prove Theorem  3. In practice, since the server does not know the global model in the current FL system is poisoned or not, we assume the model is already backdoored and derive the condition when its prediction will be certifiably consistent with the prediction of the clean model. Therefore, the reference distribution ρ=μ​(w′)𝜌𝜇superscript𝑤′\rho=\mu(w^{\prime}) and ν=μ​(w)𝜈𝜇𝑤\nu=\mu(w). Moreover, HscA​(w′;xt​e​s​t)≥pA¯superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠subscript𝑐𝐴superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡¯subscript𝑝𝐴{H_{s}^{c_{A}}}(w^{\prime};x_{test})\geq\underline{p_{A}} is equivalent to ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=+1]≥pAsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊1subscript𝑝𝐴\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=+1]\geq p_{A}, and maxc≠cA⁡Hsc​(w′;xt​e​s​t)≤pB¯subscript𝑐subscript𝑐𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑠𝑐superscript𝑤′subscript𝑥𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡¯subscript𝑝𝐵\max_{c\neq c_{A}}{H_{s}^{c}}(w^{\prime};x_{test})\leq\overline{p_{B}} is equivalent to ℙW∼ρ​[ϕ​(W)=−1]≤pBsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝑊𝜌delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑊1subscript𝑝𝐵\mathbb{P}_{W\sim\rho}[\phi(W)=-1]\leq p_{B}. Rewriting Lemma 12 leads to Theorem  3. ∎
